subject: Add block/always to tempest result file tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 15:24:17.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/tempest_run.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/b014f5253367bf8f09071b550ed38886e7b24480', 'message': 'Add block/always to tempest result file tasks

The tempest result files should always be generated, regardless of
a tempest test failure or not. With out the block/always statement,
the tempest result files would only generate if the tempest tests
succeeded. This commit adds the block/always around the result file
tasks so that they are generated when the tempest tests fail.

Change-Id: I6698d52a7209005449fdb69a35eeaad763c59da9
'}]
commit_message:
Add block/always to tempest result file tasks

The tempest result files should always be generated, regardless of
a tempest test failure or not. With out the block/always statement,
the tempest result files would only generate if the tempest tests
succeeded. This commit adds the block/always around the result file
tasks so that they are generated when the tempest tests fail.

Change-Id: I6698d52a7209005449fdb69a35eeaad763c59da9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest refs/changes/94/472294/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update vars to match latest keepalived role

While the user interface is retro-compatible, it's probably better
to adapt our vars and examples to show what's the future gonna be.

Change-Id: Ic242f98d775ccd176e69251e4734075bbbb01146

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 bytes vs strings differences

Writing files was done fairly naively with our Python 2 code - this
change introduces explicit ASCII encoding when writing files.

Change-Id: I93c9fa4ba2fd8af9c9bf9424adaec602dbdca5f0

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 dictionary incompatibilities

There were two instances of abusing old Python 2 behaviors around
dictionary keys that Python 3 no longer allows. These are both fixed.

Change-Id: I5865ee3becf52fca590a1c0c897bcd968210ac9d

commit_message:
Revert role pin for further Pike development

Now that Pike-2 has been released, we can continue to
develop against the master branches of all the roles.

Some service SHA's are also updated due to the
keystonemiddleware switch from pycrypto to cryptography.

Change-Id: Ieb103093b7cd8fbf8b8f1acffd7b07efe70ab5d9

commit_message:
Changing reconcile to test_only

In order to make the code easier to understand we came to a conclusion
that changing the variable reconcile to test_only makes more sense.

Change-Id: Ia3cca7a1615c690f9e7af6aff0a393ef0fc06e10

commit_message:
ovs fw migration from iptables

With the introduction of ovs fw, there's an odd state where old
instances are using iptables, but new instances are using ovs fw. This
patch proposes a mechanism to migrate iptables-based instances to ovs
fw.

It is expected for, during the migration run, that the nova-compute
process will be disabled ('nova service-disable') and not running, in
order to avoid race conditions that might stem from running the
migration on a port concurrently to some nova action on the instance.

The code doesn't use python-libvirt as, for some reason, the code
crashed locally (segmentation fault) during development. I'd rather
merge it as is and work during Pike to migrate it to python-libvirt.

An alternative for this patch was using 'nova interface-detach' and
'nova interface-attach'. Such an alternative is less optimal than this
solution in the sense that it necessitate a downtime for the guest it
self (actual device removal) while the port is detached (whereas this
solution just re-plugs the interface, causing a much negligible
downtime).

Closes-Bug: #1652071
Change-Id: I34be675e78a98127e184a5efc6cddd72e7a18e4a

commit_message:
Using fixtures instead of deprecated mockpatch module

This module mockpatch of oslotest[1] is deprecated since version 1.13
and may be removed in version 2.0. Use fixtures.Mock* classes instead[2]

[1]OpenStack Testing Framework and Utilities
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslotest/api/oslotest.mockpatch.html#module-oslotest.mockpatch

Change-Id: Ie54cc051829cc2370cab9cd3a7d9542e2abc51ab

commit_message:
Simplify multi arch repo build

When using repo_build, we were creating groups by architecture,
but then did complex operations to see if they were using
different os versions.

This commit simplifies this, by creating groups depending on both
arch and distribution: It improves readability, but also
fixes the issues where no group was previously created for
multiple architectures.

Change-Id: I36c3033b8a932a81d98bd85d6cfb738e77147192
Closes-Bug: #1694265
(cherry picked from commit e7800cef933938b103fd33bb93590e18e93c29d7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/45/472145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Group repo servers by architecture and os version group_by: key: repo_servers_{{ ansible_distribution_version }}_{{ ansible_architecture }} # Use the 'add_host' module to create the repo_masters group which consists of a # single host in each distribution/architecture combination. This ensures that # the repo build happens per architecture and per distribution, covering the needs # of each of these combinations when deploying. name: "{{ item }}" groups: repo_masters when: - "inventory_hostname in groups['repo_servers_' + ansible_distribution_version + '_' + ansible_architecture][0]" with_inventory_hostnames: - repo_all tags: - always hosts: repo_masters
deleted_lines: - name: Group repo servers by architecture group_by: key: repo_servers_{{ ansible_architecture }} tags: - always # Use the 'add_host' module to create the repo_nodes group. The add_hosts module # bypasses the play host loop of ansible and runs only once referencing the first # host. To run it on each host we have to use with_items. Also note, we have # to manually lookup the ansible_architecture for the 'item' host. name: "{{ groups['repo_servers_' + (hostvars[item].ansible_distribution_version.split('.')[:2] | join('.')) + hostvars[item].ansible_architecture][0] }}" groups: "repo_nodes" # Process all nodes that don't match the architecture of repo_all[0] when: > hostvars[item].ansible_architecture != hostvars[groups['repo_all'][0]].ansible_architecture or (hostvars[item].ansible_distribution_version.split('.')[:2] | join('.')) != (hostvars[groups['repo_all'][0]].ansible_distribution_version.split('.')[:2] | join('.')) with_items: - "{{ groups['repo_all'][1:] }}" tags:# repo_all[0] is built last to ensure it has all build artifacts for final indexing # The repo_nodes group will be populated with the first node of any other system running # different architectures. This group is a meta group created in the previous play and # will not be found within inventory. hosts: repo_nodes, repo_all[0]

commit_message:
Deprecate rpc_backend option

Option "rpc_backend" from group "DEFAULT" is deprecated for removal
(Replaced by [DEFAULT]/transport_url). Its value may be silently
ignored in the future.

Change-Id: Ia352ef7377e6e1f51fffb3181ad5ab422275f39a
Implements: blueprint deprecate-rpc-backend

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-07 02:52:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-panko/commit/c78f262830ffd2fbf37cc0bd86b64a8a895f8aaa', 'message': 'Fix the default port for Panko API

The port used for Panko in the puppet module is inconsistent,
incorrect and conflicts with Trove. According to the official
documentation[0] this should be 8777.

[0]https://docs.openstack.org/developer/panko/install/manual.html#installing-the-api-server

The puppet module declares the following ports:

api.pp line 79 : port 8779
panko::keystone::auth : port 8779

Please note that port 8779 has been reserved by Trove!

commit_message:
Fix the default port for Panko API

The port used for Panko in the puppet module is conflicts with Trove[1].
According to the official documentation[2] this should be 8777. The
8777 port has been occupied by ceilometer. So set the panko api port to
8977.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/etc/apache2/trove#L20
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/developer/panko/install/manual.html#installing-the-api-server

Change-Id: I53b286d1d6466b574fdb286cc45f3138f96dff59
Closes-Bug: #1691283

commit_message:
Some tweaks for modal forms

The clean up for the recent blueprint changes. Adds some
missing attributes for View classes and replaces some redundant
get_success_url methods with proper success urls.

Change-Id: I724f8c02afe7108ea06b0b8c1cfa1168159fcb00
Implements: blueprint form-templates

commit_message:
Pass packages to uninstall/install as a list

Instead of using the slower loop, pass the
list directly to the package task to do
them all at once.

Change-Id: I1c0bc0e39240834b4d6c5d525d665b015659ecbb

commit_message:
Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages is passed directly to
the package module instead of using a loop.

The package installation tasks are also made to be
more consistent.

Change-Id: I3f2fa4a0ff5f5387fe888cb2259585f00d0291e3

commit_message:
Move rebuild notification tests into separate method

The current rebuild testing in test_instance_action changes the image
used by the instance, therefore the actions tested in
test_instance_action had to be in specific order as testing rebuild
also changes the output json.

The rebuild test was moved from test_instance_action to its own method,
and now all the actions in test_instance_actions keeps the instance in
the same state.

Change-Id: Id0a7aaf8575d69deb89d3842b54fc23ee05b2153
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-pike

commit_message:
Fix device metadata service version check for multiple cells

This makes the service version check for device metadata support use the
new cross-cell helper. Without this, we could incorrectly determine that
everything is new when it is not.

Change-Id: I207dd91c447d7b0da392d333a2806a1a10e1451c
Closes-Bug: #1695993

subject: Optimise the distro package installation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 15:51:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-memcached_server/commit/4a42e2be3951e661d40a78ef3d6d15cb161eb868', 'message': 'Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages to install is prepared
for the host, then installed by passing the package
task the full list instead of using a loop.

The package lists in defaults are removed as it is
undesirable to make it easy to override these lists.

commit_message:
Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages to install is prepared
for the host, then installed by passing the package
task the full list instead of using a loop.

The package lists in defaults are removed as it is
undesirable to make it easy to override these lists.
This is not provided for in any other roles.

Change-Id: I71307d2a808fdc0f76e376a84651dad86b3f8b69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-memcached_server refs/changes/05/472305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use charms.openstack charmhelpers test_mocks

Every reactive charm that uses charms.openstack and implements unit
testing needs to mock charmhelpers, as otherwise the tests blow up.
This patch uses the mocking of charmhelpers in charms.openstack so that
a charm layer can just import test_mocks and charmhelpers will be mocked
out along with setting up a default
charmhelpers.c.o.u.OPENSTACK_RELEASES so that when an OpenStackCharm()
derived charm class won't fail on definition.

Related-Bug: #1693017
(cherry-picked from openstack/charm-aodh commit d9c11f6525d22b7262e8a1203f08a6491043f151)

Change-Id: If67336436cfcb8a3ae6ae9549e0f0683f7f3fb22
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-keystone-ldap refs/changes/98/471798/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: import mock# also stops sideeffects from occuring. charmhelpers = mock.MagicMock() apt_pkg = mock.MagicMock() sys.modules['apt_pkg'] = apt_pkg sys.modules['charmhelpers'] = charmhelpers sys.modules['charmhelpers.core'] = charmhelpers.core sys.modules['charmhelpers.core.decorators'] = charmhelpers.core.decorators sys.modules['charmhelpers.core.hookenv'] = charmhelpers.core.hookenv sys.modules['charmhelpers.core.host'] = charmhelpers.core.host sys.modules['charmhelpers.core.unitdata'] = charmhelpers.core.unitdata sys.modules['charmhelpers.core.templating'] = charmhelpers.core.templating sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib'] = charmhelpers.contrib sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.openstack'] = charmhelpers.contrib.openstack sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.openstack.utils'] = ( charmhelpers.contrib.openstack.utils) sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.openstack.templating'] = ( charmhelpers.contrib.openstack.templating) sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.network'] = charmhelpers.contrib.network sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.network.ip'] = ( charmhelpers.contrib.network.ip) sys.modules['charmhelpers.fetch'] = charmhelpers.fetch sys.modules['charmhelpers.cli'] = charmhelpers.cli sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.hahelpers'] = charmhelpers.contrib.hahelpers sys.modules['charmhelpers.contrib.hahelpers.cluster'] = ( charmhelpers.contrib.hahelpers.cluster)

Change-Id: I0629153f973daeb3bef3a6968360cbc2d427f9ad

commit_message:
api-tests: Common way to define required extensions

As some tests require extensions to be enabled on the server, this patch
introduces a new class attribute to the API base class. If any extension
defined in test class is not enabled on the server, then all tests in
the test class will be skipped.

Change-Id: I0629153f973daeb3bef3a6968360cbc2d427f9ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/54/469054/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use microversions for new style volume attachments

This adds the ability to do version discovery with Cinder to
know if we can make requests at a specific microversion, like
3.27 in the case of creating/updating/deleting volume attachments.

We will use this to attempt an attachment_create at 3.27 when
attaching a volume to an instance and if 3.27 is not available
then the calling code will need to handle CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable
and fallback to the old style attachment flow.

For new style attachments, everything will be keyed off the
BlockDeviceMapping.attachment_id field being set if we successfully
created the attachment using 3.27, so the attachment_create method
is really the only one that should care about microversions initially.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I9b6ab9f71cc58d4514127f5ea61789f187487828
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/79/469579/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinderclient import api_versions as cinder_api_versionsdef _check_microversion(url, microversion): """Checks to see if the requested microversion is supported by the current version of python-cinderclient and the volume API endpoint. :param url: Cinder API endpoint URL. :param microversion: Requested microversion. If not available at the given API endpoint URL, a CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable exception is raised. :returns: The microversion if it is available. This can be used to construct the cinder v3 client object. :raises: CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable if the microversion is not available. """ max_api_version = cinder_client.get_highest_client_server_version(url) # get_highest_client_server_version returns a float which we need to cast # to a str and create an APIVersion object to do our version comparison. max_api_version = cinder_api_versions.APIVersion(str(max_api_version)) # Check if the max_api_version matches the requested minimum microversion. if max_api_version.matches(microversion): # The requested microversion is supported by the client and the server. return microversion raise exception.CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable(version=microversion) def cinderclient(context, microversion=None): """Constructs a cinder client object for making API requests. :param context: The nova request context for auth. :param microversion: Optional microversion to check against the client. This implies that Cinder v3 is required for any calls that require a microversion. If the microversion is not available, this method will raise an CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable exception. """ if microversion is not None: # The Cinder v2 API does not support microversions. raise exception.CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable(version=microversion) # Check to see a specific microversion is requested and if so, can it # be handled by the backing server. if microversion is not None: version = _check_microversion(url, microversion)
deleted_lines: def cinderclient(context): # TODO(ildikov): Add microversion support for picking up the new # attach/detach API that was added in 3.27.

commit_message:
Skip microversion discovery check for update/delete volume attachments

We check the microversion when creating a new-style volume attachment.

If we use that API and create the volume attachment, we're going to
store the attachment id on the related BlockDeviceMapping object.

Code that's updating or deleting attachments for a BDM with the
attachment_id field set assumes that 3.27 is already available since
it was when the attachment was created, and therefore we don't need
to check the version again which saves us an extra GET / call to Cinder.

We also don't support rollbacks of the Cinder API, but if that did
happen and we requested 3.27 and it wasn't available, Cinder would
return a 406 error which would result in a compute fault.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I727fce7bbd84bcf58d7f1f91377fda35e36cbc7a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/469668/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

This should only be used if a previous check for the same microversion was successful. if skip_version_check: version = microversion else: version = _check_microversion(url, microversion) return cinderclient( context, '3.27', skip_version_check=True).attachments.update( attachment_id, connector) context, '3.27', skip_version_check=True).attachments.delete( attachment_id)

commit_message:
Use 3.27 microversion when creating new style volume attachments

Now that we have version discovery support we can explicitly
request 3.27 when creating a new-style volume attachment. If the
3.27 microversion is not available, CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable
will be raised back up to the caller, indicating an old-style
attachment needs to be made.

The same is done when updating or deleting new-style attachments.

A TODO is left inline for update and delete since we should be able
to assume that if we're updating or deleting a new style attachment,
which is keyed off the BlockDeviceMapping.attachment_id field, that
3.27 is available and we can save ourselves a GET / call to Cinder.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: Icf8cda2c34dda9e7b56a586353842dd035b115cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/469609/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set containerized_overcloud true for releases Pike and later

containerized_overcloud was defined in two roles.
This review removes the dupliacted definition and
sets the variable true for releases Pike and later and
false for releases prior to that.

commit_message:
Ensure Swift Rings backup container and URLs

Swift Rings backup container and URLs for it are created only
during deploy but there is possibility of minor update or
change of deployment when they should be created. Adding them
in plan_management update_deployment_plan fixes these cases.

Closes-Bug: #1695778
Resolves: rhbz#1455616
Change-Id: Ifcedd54da5c74f12c863b8ec63679360673dd8f6

subject: Use Deployment actions for blacklist
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-07 18:06:54.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/compute-role.yaml', 'puppet/cephstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/role.role.j2.yaml', 'puppet/objectstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/blockstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/controller-role.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/d48299cb505e8b051689207e031eb67df11237ab', 'message': 'Use Deployment actions for blacklist

Instead of using the Heat condition directly on the Deployment
resources, use it to set the action list to an empty list when the
server is blacklisted.

This has a couple advantages over the previous approach in that the
actual resources are not deleted and recreated when servers are added
and removed from the blacklist.

Recreating the resources can be problematic, as it would then force the
Deployments to re-run when a server is removed from the blacklist. That
is likely not always desirable, especially in the case of
NetworkDeloyment.

Additionally, you will still see the resources for a blacklisted server
in the stack, just with an empty set of actions. This has the benefit of
preserving the history of the previous time the Deployment was
triggered.

implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I3d0263a6319ae4871b1ae11383ae838bd2540d36
'}]
commit_message:
Use Deployment actions for blacklist

Instead of using the Heat condition directly on the Deployment
resources, use it to set the action list to an empty list when the
server is blacklisted.

This has a couple advantages over the previous approach in that the
actual resources are not deleted and recreated when servers are added
and removed from the blacklist.

Recreating the resources can be problematic, as it would then force the
Deployments to re-run when a server is removed from the blacklist. That
is likely not always desirable, especially in the case of
NetworkDeloyment.

Additionally, you will still see the resources for a blacklisted server
in the stack, just with an empty set of actions. This has the benefit of
preserving the history of the previous time the Deployment was
triggered.

implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I3d0263a6319ae4871b1ae11383ae838bd2540d36

commit_message:

tripleo-common, otherwise we get dependency issues.

commit_message:
Fix problem that old releases do not know up-to-date release names

Old versions of Ubuntu or Debian do not know the names of the new
releases, example: debian-jessie has no idea about ubuntu-xenial.
This knowledge is needed to call debootstrap.

This patch adds a very small data set that provides a mapping between
release and script names.

Change-Id: Id25712166d2fae23d3cd5ceb72940cd321bb1340
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/98/415998/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Some release names of up-to-date Debian and Ubuntu releases are not known to old systems and therefore a debootstrap failed on these old systems. This version fixes the problem by providing a small alias data set.

commit_message:
Refactor: Clean up state initialization

This patch cleans up initialization of the block device's 'state'
dictionary.  It is not always created in the constructor and the
entry '_loaded' flags if this state was loaded or not.

Change-Id: I5e7d3a55e86109fb7c3e79a6e3cf600381c73675
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/68/468768/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The ``state`` (resp. ``results``) dictionary contains always the key ``_loaded``. If the ``state`` object was loaded this is set to ``True`` - if it was not loaded it is set to ``False``.

commit_message:
Refactor: Generalize parameters passed to plugins

The funtion 'create_graph()' is a generic function and does
not need to know which and how many parameters are passed
on to the plugin constructor.

This patch generalizes the parameter passing.

This patch is needed for upcoming patches that eliminate the globals
in block device handling.

Change-Id: Ib8e14dbfa5d822b8e49f93c7861f2df13236eb46
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/09/468709/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_graph(config, *args, **kwargs): :param args: arguments passed to the plugin constructor :param kwargs: keyword arguments passed to the plugin constructor cfg_obj = plugin(cfg_obj_val, *args, **kwargs)
deleted_lines: def create_graph(config, default_config): :param default_config: default parameters (from --params) cfg_obj = plugin(cfg_obj_val, default_config)

commit_message:
Refactor: Pass 'state' to plugin constructor

Currently the 'state' object is passed in to some methods of the
plugin object (only).
This patch passes in the state object already at construction
time of the plugin objects.  They have now the possibility to
use the state object directly during initialization (e.g. config
check).

Change-Id: I1cdc8b20373c5d582ea928cfd7334469ff36dbce
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/16/468716/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: graph and used for edge relationships. In addition the ``state`` object is passed in to the constructor. That makes it possible that even during initializion (e.g. config check) the state can be accessed. Implementations must ensure they initalize these fields; e.g. def __init__(name, state, arg1, ...): super(FooNode, self).__init__(name, state) def __init__(self, name, state): """Constructs a NodeBase Arguments: :param name: The unique name of the node. :param state: A shared dictionary of current state, i.e. prior results. This dictionary is passed by reference to each NodeBase object, meaning any entries inserted will be available to all ``NodeBase`` objects. """ self.state = state def get_state(self): return self.state def create(self, rollback): def umount(self): def cleanup(self): def delete(self): The ``__init__`` function will be passed three arguments: ``state`` The global state dictionary. def __init__(self, config, defaults, state):
deleted_lines: graph and used for edge relationships. Implementations must ensure they initalize it; e.g. def __init__(name, arg1, ...): super(FooNode, self).__init__(name) def __init__(self, name): def create(self, results, rollback): :param results: A shared dictionary of prior results. This dictionary is passed by reference to each call, meaning any entries inserted will be available to subsequent :func:`create` calls of following nodes. def umount(self, state): :param state: the current state dictionary. This is the `results` dictionary from :func:`create` before this call is made. def cleanup(self, state): :param state: the current state dictionary. This is the `results` dictionary from :func:`create` before this call is made. def delete(self, state): :param state: the current state dictionary. This is the `results` dictionary from :func:`create` before this call is made. The ``__init__`` function will be passed two arguments: def __init__(self, config, defaults):

commit_message:
Refactor: Remove globals from block device mkfs and mount

There were some global variables in these modules.  These
modules are now using the 'state' to store the internal
information.

(This finishes this patch stack.)

Change-Id: Ic3b805f9258128d5233b21ff25579c03487c7fcc
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
Run ansible-lint under pep8 envlist

Start linting our ansible playbooks, this is helpful to find basic
syntax / formatting errors.

Change-Id: I3bbc3ef559523bd4096ec160c9716ec51c3bef4f
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-roles refs/changes/98/466898/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: whitelist_externals = bash commands = flake8 {posargs} bash -c "cd roles; find . -type f -regex '.*.y[a]?ml' -print0 | xargs -t -n1 -0 \ ansible-lint"

commit_message:
Add tox.ini

Add tox.ini file for pep8 setup and corresponding test-requirements
file.

Change-Id: I2b738238398b9ca1f6516fb4bd3219c120808604
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-roles refs/changes/53/462253/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [tox] minversion = 1.6 skipsdist = True envlist = pep8, py27 [testenv] usedevelop = True install_command = pip install {opts} {packages} deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args='{posargs}' [testenv:bindep] # Do not install any requirements. We want this to be fast and work even if # system dependencies are missing, since it's used to tell you what system # dependencies are missing! This also means that bindep must be installed # separately, outside of the requirements files. deps = bindep commands = bindep test [testenv:pep8] commands = flake8 {posargs} [testenv:venv] commands = {posargs} [flake8] # These are ignored intentionally in openstack-infra projects; # please don't submit patches that solely correct them or enable them. ignore = E125,E129,H show-source = True exclude = .venv,.tox,dist,doc,build,*.egg

commit_message:
Gather facts for run-bindep role

Because we want to use the package task, we need to know facts about
the host we are running on. Otherwise we get the following error:

  Could not detect which package manager to use. Try gathering facts
  or setting the "use" option.

Change-Id: I069f4025403e301af08137c19da1e5b35e21798d
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/63/472363/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data = self._volume_client.get( '/types', params=dict(is_public='None'), error_message='Error fetching volume_type list') return self._normalize_volume_types( data.get('volume_types', [])) data = self._volume_client.post( '/volumes', json=dict(payload), error_message='Error in creating volume') volume = data.get('volume', {})
deleted_lines: with _utils.shade_exceptions("Error fetching volume_type list"): data = self._volume_client.get( '/types', params=dict(is_public='None')) return self._normalize_volume_types( data.get('volume_types', [])) with _utils.shade_exceptions("Error in creating volume"): data = self._volume_client.post( '/volumes', json=dict(payload)) volume = data.get('volume', {})

subject: Allow service running state check through pgid
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-27 16:50:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/grenade/commit/a85fbcd969b193ac7ebe6da7d9ed1bf6e91dc635', 'message': "Allow service running state check through pgid

If service name doesn't match service process command line, state
detection falis in inc/upgrade:is_service_running.
Ironic-inspector-dhcp service for instance executes a dnsmasq process
that, although running, will not match its service name.

Suggested patch infers service running state through pid file in case
name matching fails.

Change-Id: I81f851ff1c9bb2f8722921db347d7f9d9262d952
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-28 06:48:43.000000000', 'files': ['inc/upgrade'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/grenade/commit/0947c8be8ad1042d97bafad0de4f404a162fbf12', 'message': "Allow service running state check through pgid

If service name doesn't match service process command line, state
detection falis in inc/upgrade:is_service_running.
Ironic-inspector-dhcp service for instance executes a dnsmasq process
that, although running, will not match its service name.

commit_message:
Allow service running state check through pgid

If service name doesn't match service process command line, state
detection falis in inc/upgrade:is_service_running.
Ironic-inspector-dhcp service for instance executes a dnsmasq process
that, although running, will not match its service name.

Suggested patch infers service running state through pid file in case
name matching fails.

Change-Id: I81f851ff1c9bb2f8722921db347d7f9d9262d952
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/64/334564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # - ``SERVICE_DIR`` # - ``SCREEN_NAME`` ps auxw | grep -v grep | grep -v shutdown.sh | grep -v upgrade.sh | grep -e "${name}" && return $? # in case service name differs from service process cmd line ps -fg $(cat $SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$name.pid)
deleted_lines: ps auxw | grep -v grep | grep -v shutdown.sh | grep -v upgrade.sh | grep -e "${name}" local exitcode=$? # some times I really hate bash reverse binary logic return $exitcode

commit_message:
Permanent node cache

In order to reduce synchronization with ironic, the node_status_keep_time
service configuration option was deprecated and is silently ignored now.
This change will simplify the DHCP PXE boot filter maintenance and was
suggested in the Multiple filtering backends specification[1]

Partial-Bug: 1665666

[1]
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-inspector-specs/specs/multiple-pxe-filtering-backends.html

Change-Id: I72f7ab78064544f3e3a08dffce0700c8b7bd0535
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/50/451350/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # DEPRECATED: For how much time (in seconds) to keep status # information about nodes after introspection was finished for them. # Default value is 1 week. (integer value) # This option is deprecated for removal. # Its value may be silently ignored in the future. # Reason: Reduce ironic synchronization.# List of Etherent Over InfiniBand interfaces on the Inspector host # which are used for physical access to the DHCP network. Multiple # interfaces would be attached to a bond or bridge specified in # dnsmasq_interface. The MACs of the InfiniBand nodes which are not in # desired state are going to be blacklisted based on the list of # neighbor MACs on these interfaces. (list value)

commit_message:
Extended description of OPENSTACK_HOST setting

This change extends the description of OPENSTACK_HOST, now including
references to other settings that explain how to setup multiple region in
Horizon.

commit_message:
Use get_rpc_transport instead of get_transport

With the added get_rpc_transport() function in oslo.messaging [1]
and the recent version bump of oslo.messaging to 5.24.2, we can
safely replace get_transport() with get_rpc_transport() which is much
cleaner.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/454194/

Related-Bug: #1680192
Change-Id: I6b2ee043048bc380c4dd75638817f8152617ce09

commit_message:
Use TEMPEST_REGEX in new keystone job

We need to set the regex in order for tempest to run with tox -eall
instead of tox -esmoke so that the plugin tests are actually included,
as well as to reduce the number of tests to just the plugin-specific
ones.

Change-Id: I438261e9d29c488067522eb7f50cc3c963753836

commit_message:
Fix grenade test related to encrypt volume/image

DevStack Ocata version and master use different default images
(Ocata:uec and master:qcow2), this will lead to tempest encrypt test
failure in grenade gate.

This patch hard-code default images in base version and will be
removed if devstack master and ocata patches are proposed.

Change-Id: I997c759fc026366fe48de9ac7e8c58941622c9cd
Co-Authored-By: Nam Nguyen Hoai <namnh@vn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/66/471566/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(hieulq): devstack ocata and master use different default image (ocata-uec, master-qcow2), thus the grenade test will fail # We should config the same image for base and target devstack, and remove this config when devstack fixes are proposed devstack_localrc base DEFAULT_IMAGE_FILE_NAME=cirros-${CIRROS_VERSION}-${CIRROS_ARCH}-disk.img devstack_localrc base IMAGE_URLS="http://download.cirros-cloud.net/${CIRROS_VERSION}/${DEFAULT_IMAGE_FILE_NAME}"

commit_message:
Change volume metadata not to use nested dicts

Ironic sets metadata to a volume when attaching and detaching. However,
Cinder doesn't accept metadata which consists of nested dictionaries.
This patch fixes the issue by passing metadata as string without
nested dictionaries.

Change-Id: Ibe0a752a923ff52526a7e04374e61c14f6c4f0b0
Partial-Bug: #1559691

subject: Make sync_routers chunking configurable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-26 13:38:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9db2bc135e1b9ae72ca73471a3628c165cd8b07f', 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.i

Normally when the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout
exception occures the agent will start decreasing the chunk size.i

When the neutron-server is under heavy load it takes too long until
the agent starts chunking up the sync_routers rpc calls and by that
time the server might already be too busy to answer the smaller calls.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra tunables
to set while keeping the old defaults in place.

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-05-26 13:42:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d5a77f0edcee2ae7c74b23de7750b2120ac54bce', 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.i

Normally when the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout
exception occures the agent will start decreasing the chunk size.i

When the neutron-server is under heavy load it takes too long until
the agent starts chunking up the sync_routers rpc calls and by that
time the server might already be too busy to answer the smaller calls.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra tunables
to set while keeping the old defaults in place.

Closes-Bug: 1692971

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-05-29 14:11:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6412ba572a1d37c9df4b360db262bd99c584d0dd', 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.i

Normally when the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout
exception occures the agent will start decreasing the chunk size.i

When the neutron-server is under heavy load it takes too long until
the agent starts chunking up the sync_routers rpc calls and by that
time the server might already be too busy to answer the smaller calls.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra tunables
to set while keeping the old defaults in place.

Closes-Bug: 1692971
DocImpact: add two more configs to the L3 agent to control
           chunking for the sync_routers RPC call

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-05-30 07:19:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5ca0c5599ada773228533f9fc3539688fdc26a13', 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.

When the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout exception
occures the agent will start decreasing the chunk size. The time it
takes to trigger MessagingTimeout depends on the ``rpc_response_timeout``
configuration parameter.

The current back-off logic implemented in ``neutron/common/rpc.py``
is to increase the rpc_response_timeout up to 10 times before resoting
to chunking. In effect this tries to scale up the RPC response timeout
window but still floods the server with calls that take several minutes
to process.

We observed that in environments with multiple L3 agents (more than 6)
and high number of routers pe agent (more than 240) the RCP call to
sync_routes behaves exponentially instead of linearly.

The solution that the neutron-server advertises in the logs (to increase
the ``rpc_response_timeout``) only increases the traffic outage instead
of providing a mitigation.

During our experiments we oserved that lower values for the
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE (tested with 64 and 32) allows the server
to respond within the timeout window and leads to a total recoveryi
within 3-5 minutes. While in theory this might increase the time needed
for the agent to fully recover due to trickling the list of routers
from the server, the observed behavior in practice is that it avoids
the unnecessary increase in ``rpc_response_timeout`` and completes
the agent recovery within and acceptable time window.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra tunables
to set while keeping the old defaults in place.

Closes-Bug: #1692971
DocImpact: add two advanced configuration options to the L3 agent
           to control the chunking behavior for the sync_routers
           RPC call

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2017-05-30 09:12:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8e8918c8ac1d5ff34c849bc0d1cc896ff24bade2', 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

commit_message:
Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.

When the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout exception
occurs the agent will start decreasing the chunk size. The time it
takes to trigger MessagingTimeout depends on the ``rpc_response_timeout``
configuration parameter.

The current back-off logic implemented in ``neutron/common/rpc.py``
is to increase the rpc_response_timeout up to 10 times before resorting
to chunking. In effect this tries to scale up the RPC response timeout
window but still floods the server with calls that take several minutes
to process.

We observed that, in environments with multiple L3 agents (more than 6)
and a high number of routers per agent (more than 240), the RPC call to
sync_routes behaves exponentially instead of linearly.

The solution that the neutron-server advertises in the logs (to increase
the ``rpc_response_timeout``) defeats the point of chunking in the first
place and only increases the traffic outage instead of providing a
mitigation.

During our experiments we oserved that lower values for the
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE (tested with 64 and 32) allows the server
to respond within the timeout window and leads to a total recovery
within 3-5 minutes. While in theory this might increase the time needed
for the agent to fully recover due to trickling the list of routers
from the server, the observed behavior in practice is that it avoids
the unnecessary increase in ``rpc_response_timeout`` and completes
the agent recovery within and acceptable time window.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra advanced
tunables to set while keeping the old defaults in place for everyone
else.

Closes-Bug: #1692971
DocImpact: add two advanced configuration options to the L3 agent
           to control the chunking behavior for the sync_routers
           RPC call

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/21/468421/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('sync_routers_max_chunk_size', default=256, min=1, help=_('Initial chunk size for the number of routers to fetch ' 'in a single resync call to the server. Decrease this to ' 'reduce the load on overloaded servers by sending ' 'multiple smaller requests and avoid a cascading failure ' 'effect.')), cfg.IntOpt('sync_routers_min_chunk_size', default=32, min=1, max='$sync_routers_max_chunk_size', help=_('Minimum chunk size for the number of routers to fetch ' 'in a single resync call to the server. Make sure this is ' 'at most half of sync_routers_max_chunk_size to allow the ' 'agent to scale down the chunk size.')),

commit_message:
master-undercloud-ocata-overcloud: tripleo-common subpackages from delorean-current

We need to install tripleo-common-containers from the same repo as
tripleo-common, otherwise we get dependency issues.

Change-Id: Ie8c93502d248e9aac024df66e218c4e1cb8ceb40
Partial-Bug: #1696726

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-15 19:09:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/8c9bf669d0cee3270bdf69d6cf07739573553ef2', 'message': 'Role definitions

As we create new standard roles, we should include them from a single
location for ease of use and to reduce the duplication of the role
definitions elsewhere. This change adds a roles folder to the THT along
with a python script to allow the end user to generate a roles_data.yaml
from a standard set of roles.  This script allows a user to dynamically
generate the file from our given set of pre-canned roles.

Change-Id: Iad3e9b215c6f21ba761c8360bb7ed531e34520e6
Related-Blueprint: example-custom-role-environments
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-03-15 20:29:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/bbb7c1950f306d7f4cc30f7e668eb1db03b213ad', 'message': 'Standardize example role definitions

As we create new standard roles, we should include them from a single
location for ease of use and to reduce the duplication of the role
definitions elsewhere. This change adds a roles folder to the THT along
with a python script to allow the end user to generate a roles_data.yaml
from a standard set of roles.  This script allows a user to dynamically
generate the file from our given set of pre-canned roles.

Included in this change is a new tox environment called generate_roles
which will automatically generate the roles_data.yaml and
roles_data_undercloud.yaml using the roles from the new roles folder.

commit_message:
Standardize example role definitions

As we create new standard roles, we should include them from a single
location for ease of use and to reduce the duplication of the role
definitions elsewhere. This change adds a roles folder to the THT that
can be used with the new roles commands in python-tripleoclient by the
end user to generate a roles_data.yaml from a standard set of roles.

Depends-On: I326bae5bdee088e03aa89128d253612ef89e5c0c
Change-Id: Iad3e9b215c6f21ba761c8360bb7ed531e34520e6
Related-Blueprint: example-custom-role-environments

commit_message:
Expose metric delay processing metric

For performance reasons we might want to tweak this param
lets expose this via tripleo. The puppet changes were
added in this patch I5de5283d1b14e0bba63d6d9a440611914ba86ca4

Change-Id: I72f1fe3a47060fe37602a70b8a74fba72209127c
(cherry picked from commit e33e76684c9b60b9ce50ad7996529ed49dddd9d9)

commit_message:
Limit number of revert tombstone SSYNC requests

Revert tombstone only parts try to talk to all primary nodes - this
fixes it to randomize selection within part_nodes. Corresponding probe
test is modified to reflect this change.

The primary improvement of this patch is the reconstuctor at a handoff
node is being able to delete local tombstones when it succeeds to sync
to less than all primary nodes. (Before this patch, it requires all
nodes are responsible for the REVERT requests)

The number of primary nodes to communicate with the reconstructor can be
in dicsussion more but, right now with this patch, it's (replicas - k + 1)
that is able to prevent stale read.

*BONUS*

- Fix mis-testsetting (was setting less replicas than ec_k + ec_m)
  for reconstructor ring in the unit test

Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I05ce8fe75f1c4a7971cc8995b003df818b69b3c1
Closes-Bug: #1668857

subject: Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge for consistency
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-17 21:57:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b6006ded508dd4516881bc636448e5092be0e7b7', 'message': 'test

Change-Id: I23c5faaeab69aede1fd038a36f4a0b8f928498ce
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-18 01:00:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/311edbb1e331e8c368e67686274ec0c030720507', 'message': "Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge

This adjusts the Linux Bridge mechanism driver to return
the 'tap' VIF type to Nova since the agent now handles wiring
up compute ports (I2a23d0cbc4c4d0db6e9f48d91ca03b5007f91a84).

This completely eliminates all of the work Nova was doing with
regard to bridges so we now have one consistent path how ports
(both compute and dhcp/l3) are connected into Linux Bridge
networks. Both Nova and the DHCP/L3 agents will now just create
a device and leave wiring to bridges to be completely the
responsibility of the L2 agent.

In order to preserve backwards compatibiliy with Ocata agents
that won't touch compute ports, we only report back vif_type='tap'
if the agent has a config value showing that it wires compute
ports.

This will also solve a longstanding bug (bug #1105488) that
is preventing Nova instances from using custom bridge mappings
since the agent will be guaranteed to be responsible for the
connection to the bridge.

Depends-On: I95cc18652700d63230e6bcd2018595b7551361d5

Closes-Bug: #1673910
Closes-Bug: #1105488
Change-Id: I23c5faaeab69aede1fd038a36f4a0b8f928498ce
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-03-20 20:42:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/cab7bbbb2bb28fadef3b5489774ec22df510e98f', 'message': "Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge for consistency

responsibility of the L2 agent.

In order to preserve backwards compatibiliy with Ocata agents
that won't touch compute ports, we only report back vif_type='tap'
if the agent has a report_state value showing that it wires compute
ports.

This will also solve a longstanding bug (bug #1105488) that

commit_message:
Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge for consistency

This adjusts the Linux Bridge mechanism driver to return
the 'tap' VIF type to Nova so the Linux Bridge agent is
responsible for plugging all ports into bridges.

This completely eliminates all of the work Nova was doing with
regard to bridges so we now have one consistent path how ports
(both compute and dhcp/l3) are connected into Linux Bridge
networks. Both Nova and the DHCP/L3 agents will now just create
a device and leave wiring to bridges to be completely the
responsibility of the L2 agent.

In order to preserve backwards compatibiliy with Ocata agents
that won't touch compute ports, we only report back vif_type='tap'
if the agent has a report_state value showing that it wires compute
ports.

This will also solve a longstanding bug (bug #1105488) that
is preventing Nova instances from using custom bridge mappings
since the agent will be guaranteed to be responsible for the
connection to the bridge.

Depends-On: I075595158d8f3b5a6811c4794aa7b91912940db5

Related-Bug: #1617447
Closes-Bug: #1673910
Closes-Bug: #1105488
Change-Id: I23c5faaeab69aede1fd038a36f4a0b8f928498ce

Amulet utils support for Juju 2.x

Amulet test fixes to run under Juju 2.x.

Change-Id: Ice38f9a0f0e0e6bfe461abed46bfe08f113372c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-keystone refs/changes/07/439207/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from distutils.version import LooseVersion # amulet juju action helpers: if self.juju_min_version("2.0"): command = ["juju", "run-action", "--format=json", unit_id, action] else: command = ["juju", "action", "do", "--format=json", unit_id, action] if self.juju_min_version("2.0"): command = ["juju", "show-action-output", "--format=json", "--wait=0", action_id] else: command = ["juju", "action", "fetch", "--format=json", "--wait=0", action_id] def juju_version(self): """Return Juju version @reutrns string version """ cmd = ['juju', 'version'] return subprocess.check_output(cmd) def juju_min_version(self, minimum_version='2.0'): """Return True if the Juju version is at least the provided version @returns boolean """ return (LooseVersion(self.juju_version()) >= LooseVersion(minimum_version))
deleted_lines: # amulet juju action helpers: command = ["juju", "action", "do", "--format=json", unit_id, action] command = ["juju", "action", "fetch", "--format=json", "--wait=0", action_id]

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: Ic4c7ee1d36ee58c31a91d094801683b6a5a47b9f
Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
Fix doc generation for Python3

Fix the Sphinx html_last_updated_fmt for Python3.
The html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I2602ec196968dd37ea87899ef4a257e7519cecec
Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
Move role policies to DocumentedRuleDefault

A new policy class was introduced that requires
additional parameters when defining policy objects.

This patch switches our role policy object to
the policy.DocumentedRuleDefault and fills the
required policy parameters as needed.

Co-Authored-By: Samriddhi Jain <j.samriddhi13@gmail.com>
Partially-Implements: bp policy-docs
Change-Id: I29714c9b4019e2e31f228ef767e93f65572c106b

commit_message:
Merge pylint in pep8 check

This allows pylint to run in the pep8 gate

Fix a missing parameter spotted by pylint
Also update .pylintrc to re-enable some checks

Change-Id: I2fc75235105e94df05822169d0eca947572fe8b2

Change-Id: I95ab2b58e2895c7735cc5a65dbf401bbd7715ccf
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-05-26 17:20:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/8bc2e74024e6ef1b0a6053ee5e7496f7f0b48720', 'message': 'First Pass: De-client-ify list_users

Change-Id: I95ab2b58e2895c7735cc5a65dbf401bbd7715ccf
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-06-04 17:03:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/525f8e35dab1ed822a7d8b16b02c89232fdeff0a', 'message': "First Pass: De-client-ify list_users

keystoneclient has a different world-view on version discovery. As soon
as we start having some of the calls be shade/keystoneauth, the first
call keystoneclient makes will inject a discovery call (it does not use
the keystoneauth discovery cache)

This means we'll basically need to do many more calls in one pass to
avoid double-discovery which will blow our mocks. It's possible it means
doing all of the calls in one patch - but there may be smaller groupings
of overlapping calls.

It gets even more complex, because we have an entry for the
discovery call that ksc was making at the top of each test. The way the
discovery code is written in shade right now ALSO doesn't re-use the
keystoneauth discovery cache. That means that a wholesale replacement
of calls with the shade discovery code as written will wind up testing
properly. BUT - once we're done with the replacement, we should fix the
discovery code to try using
keystoneauth.Session.get_endpoint(version=api_version) as the first
step, which in the identity call case will allow us to remove the extra
identity discovery call since it would re-use the ksa cache for the
identity discovery call which ksa always makes as the first step before
authenticating. But that should be a follow on to the removal, because
this is complicated enough as it is.

Change-Id: I95ab2b58e2895c7735cc5a65dbf401bbd7715ccf
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2017-06-04 19:48:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/056e41395928695c2688fd2707913106d21f3ace', 'message': "First Pass: De-client-ify list_users

This means we'll basically need to do many more calls in one pass to

It gets even more complex, because we have an entry for the

discovery code is written in shade right now ALSO doesn't re-use the

commit_message:
De-client-ify User Ops

Remove keystoneclient from some user CRUD ops.

Change-Id: I95ab2b58e2895c7735cc5a65dbf401bbd7715ccf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/84/467784/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Get configured api version for downgrades config_version = self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') identity_client = self._get_raw_client('identity') identity_url = self.cloud_config.config.get('identity_endpoint_override') if not identity_url: image_url = self._discover_identity_endpoint( config_version, identity_client) identity_client.endpoint_override = identity_url self._raw_clients['identity'] = identity_client return self._raw_clients['identity'] if 'identity' not in self._raw_clients: def _match_given_endpoint(self, given, version): def _discover_identity_endpoint(self, config_version, identity_client): try: # this is a replica of the _discover_image_endpoint, but # identity-specific. soooooooooooooo... # First - quick check to see if the endpoint in the catalog # is a versioned endpoint that matches the version we requested. # If it is, don't do any addtional work. catalog_endpoint = identity_client.get_endpoint() if self._match_given_endpoint(catalog_endpoint, config_version): return catalog_endpoint # version discovery versions = identity_client.get('/')['values'] api_version = None if config_version.startswith('2'): api_version = [ version for version in versions if version['id'] == 'v2.0'] if api_version: api_version = api_version[0] if config_version.startswith('3'): api_version = [ version for version in versions if version['id'].startswith('v3')][0] identity_url = api_version['links'][0]['href'] # If we detect a different version that was configured, # set the version in occ because we have logic elsewhere # that is different depending on which version we're using warning_msg = None if (config_version.startswith('2') and api_version['id'].startswith('v2')): self.cloud_config.config['identity_api_version'] = '3' warning_msg = ( 'identity_api_version is 3 but only 2 is available.') elif (config_version.startswith('2') and api_version['id'].startswith('v3')): self.cloud_config.config['identity_api_version'] = '2' warning_msg = ( 'identity_api_version is 2 but only 3 is available.') if warning_msg: self.log.debug(warning_msg) warnings.warn(warning_msg) except (keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure, OpenStackCloudURINotFound) as e: # A 404 or a connection error is a likely thing to get # either with a misconfgured glance. or we've already # gotten a versioned endpoint from the catalog self.log.debug( "Keystone version discovery failed, assuming endpoint in" " the catalog is already versioned. {e}".format(e=str(e))) identity_url = identity_client.get_endpoint() # Sometimes version discovery documents have broken endpoints, but # the catalog has good ones (what?) catalog_endpoint = urllib.parse.urlparse( identity_client.get_endpoint()) discovered_endpoint = urllib.parse.urlparse(identity_url) return urllib.parse.ParseResult( catalog_endpoint.scheme, catalog_endpoint.netloc, discovered_endpoint.path, discovered_endpoint.params, discovered_endpoint.query, discovered_endpoint.fragment).geturl() if self._match_given_endpoint( version = self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') uri_parts = ['users'] if version in ('3', ): uri_parts.insert(0, 'v3') rest_uri = '/'.join(uri_parts) return _utils.normalize_users(self._identity_client.get(rest_uri))
deleted_lines: def _match_given_image_endpoint(self, given, version): if self._match_given_image_endpoint( with _utils.shade_exceptions("Failed to list users"): users = self.manager.submit_task(_tasks.UserList()) return _utils.normalize_users(users)

commit_message:
Run minification and tree shaking on build

"npm run build" now builds an artifact optimized for production use.  The
removes dead code, and minizes the result.  The size of the bundle shrinks from
about 14MB to 2MB.

The previous build command is moved to "npm run build:dev".

Change-Id: I21430f06049c4eeeb4a66c7143da8c2919fb5a24
Closes-Bug: 1688610

full-deploy-ovb forces OPT_NODES value to a config under general_config

Change-Id: Ia9b9014d27a7f0f199d161b7274fbcb95b2c33ed
"}]
commit_message:
Handle exising node file definition in full deploy script

full-deploy-ovb forces OPT_NODES value to a config under general_config
This change sets it only as default only if it wasn't already set.

Change-Id: Ia9b9014d27a7f0f199d161b7274fbcb95b2c33ed

commit_message:
Tag releases for os-*-config repos

These got missed when we tagged the other TripleO rc1 releases,
and are needed to have a release that uncaps pbr.

Change-Id: I36b552c3585a6fa3e1be0344a1d57a7acf345352

commit_message:
Pre-upgrade: Check disk space

This patch adds a playbook to the pre-upgrade group that checks if the
undercloud disk has at least 10GB left for an upgrade.

The tasks from the existing undercloud-disk-space validation
(pre-deployment) are extracted into a separate file and reused.

Change-Id: I193fb6e9cbbe29726f312a273b30a1839da6e261
Implements: blueprint pre-upgrade-validations
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/86/471686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: - name: Set a constant defining number of Bytes in 1 GB set_fact: const_bytes_in_gb: 1073741824 - name: Verify disk space in /var (if it exists) fail: msg="The available space on the /var partition is {{ (item.size_available|int / const_bytes_in_gb|int)|round(1) }} GB, but it should be at least {{ min_undercloud_disk_gb }} GB." with_items: "{{ ansible_mounts }}" when: "'/var' == '{{ item.mount }}'" failed_when: "{{ min_undercloud_disk_gb|int * const_bytes_in_gb|int }} >= {{ item.size_available|int }}" # Notify the next task that we've checked /var (and that it exists) changed_when: True register: previous - name: Verify root disk space fail: msg="The available space on the root partition is {{ (item.size_available|int / const_bytes_in_gb|int)|round(1) }} GB, but it should be at least {{ min_undercloud_disk_gb }} GB." with_items: "{{ ansible_mounts }}" # Only run this when /var doesn't exist when: "{{ not previous.changed }} and '/' == '{{ item.mount }}'" failed_when: "{{ min_undercloud_disk_gb|int * const_bytes_in_gb|int }} >= {{ item.size_available|int }}"

commit_message:
Fixing types.MethodType signature for Python 3.5

The signature for MethodType has changed in Python 3,
and the current implementation won't work, to fix this
we are replacing it with the py 2/3 compatible
python-six equivalent, six.create_unbound_method.
http://six.readthedocs.io/#six.create_unbound_method

This is causing the Python 3.5 tests to fail for the
octavia-dashboard when importing the navigation.py
file, throwing the following error.
> TypeError: method expected 2 arguments, got 3

The following review to fix the gate for the
octavia-dashboard is depending on this patch.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/471611/

This can also be reproduced by simply executing
navigation.py using Python 3.5.
> python3.5 nagivation.py

Change-Id: Iebca15ae962a1aa0825c6ba6d482206531726696

commit_message:
RBAC tests for image_size compute policy action.

Add RBAC tests related to the ``image_size`` compute policy action:
"os_compute_api:image-size".

Note that if Patrole is enhanced to test multiple policies
simultaneously, these policy actions can be combined with the related
tests from ``ImagesRbacTest`` class in the same file.

Change-Id: Ifcf83daa61741be3d694d07b85fcd5ac6f616f46

commit_message:
[ci][samples] Reduce redundant authentications

While validating a single sample, rally obtains a new deployment object
from the database. Since we have hundreds of samples, validation of each
single sample performs redundant steps, such as authentication.

This patch mocks obtaining deployment objects with special method
get_credentials_for with cache mechanism.

Change-Id: I51d6e3aa7897c100d114f978883cd4526b0222ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/80/472180/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
import mock # NOTE(andreykurilin): mock obtaining deployment from database to share # one cache of clients(it will allow to avoid hundreds of redundant # authentications) between validations of different samples deployment = rapi.deployment._get("MAIN") deployment_patcher = mock.patch("rally.api.objects.Deployment.get") m_deployment = deployment_patcher.start() m_deployment.return_value = deployment self.addCleanup(deployment_patcher.stop()) # store all failures and print them at once """List all samples and render task configs""" """Validate one sample""" "See details below:
%s" % "".join(["
======
%s

%s
" % (k, v)

commit_message:
Switch instack-undercloud to cycle-with-intermediary

This is required for If07880e4bc25cffe485704772d64f62288a1a53d so
we can stop using the bash layer of indirection between tripleoclient
and instack-undercloud.  In order to do that, we need to be able to
depend on instack-undercloud directly, but it can't go into g-r
with its current release model.  This release model better reflects
the intended use of instack-undercloud as a library instead of a
CLI in its own right.

Change-Id: I42235d13acf617f3bcbf22cd737ebf21378902b4

commit_message:
release keystoneauth

This release provides support for setting global_request_id on
session, which makes it easier for clients to support
global_request_id.

Change-Id: Ia9cba737a4f937b379e772cac7a85fa4ccb04172

commit_message:
Don't remove top-container element for volume REST API calls

This is a first step in the process of removing the logic
from the shade.Adapter that removes top-container element from
the REST PAI response. The goal is to simplify the logic and
move it into the REST API calls.

Change-Id: I885ba0c8d1df8c6f33bd3e2e92d052a1614a917f
Signed-off-by: Rosario Di Somma <rosario.disomma@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Use get_discovery from keystoneauth

If we use the get_discovery call, we'll re-use the keystoneauth cache.
This removes the last stupid extra discovery call.

While doing this, noticed the dns version discovery was wrong, but we
weren't noticing because adapter magic. Fix it.

Change-Id: I01d07554d094fffd498f21a9291710c8eb0041f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/01/471501/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

If it is, don't do any additional work. if not versions and config_version: versions = [config_version] candidate_endpoints = [] # Next, try built-in keystoneauth discovery so that we can take # advantage of the discovery cache base_url = self._strip_version_from_endpoint(catalog_endpoint) try: discovery = self.keystone_session.auth.get_discovery( self.keystone_session, base_url) version_list = discovery.version_data(reverse=True) if config_version: # If we have a specific version request, look for it first. for version_data in version_list: if str(version_data['version'][0]) == config_version: candidate_endpoints.append(version_data) if not candidate_endpoints: # If we didn't find anything, look again, this time either # for the range, or just grab everything if we don't have # a range if str(version_data['version'][0]) in versions: candidate_endpoints.append(version_data) elif not config_version and not versions: candidate_endpoints.append(version_data) except keystoneauth1.exceptions.DiscoveryFailure as e: # If we got more than one, pick the highest service_endpoint = endpoint_description['url'] api_version = str(endpoint_description['version'][0]) api_version = self._get_version_from_endpoint(catalog_endpoint) image_url = self._discover_endpoint( 'image', version_required=True, versions=['2', '1'])

commit_message:
Require python-novaclient >= 9.0.0

This introduces the new global_request_id parameter which is needed
for cross service request ids. Make this the minimum version so that
projects can depend on this parameter existing in the constructor.

Change-Id: I5b247f75edeea9da50fe524eadf5f9a2c626d665

commit_message:
Fix condition_map type checking for strings

The explit type checking in condition_match is broken at the very
least for strings. For now, go ahead and explicitly handle the
string case. In the future, we should evaluate why that code block
was added in the first place.

Change-Id: I730503e655ece8e862874679f00a5980a3d0e7a2

commit_message:
objects: Add old_attachment_id to BlockDeviceMapping

The spec for nova's use of the cinder v3 api calls for migrate
to create a new attachment on the destination host, and rollback
to the old attachment on a failure.

I8acc30502ba6e9ff061ca2d80fa73f6da2be7cef

To enable that, we need a place to store the old attachment_id
in the bdm. This updates the bdm with this new old_attachment_id
field.

Change-Id: Ib81f54486a68a8142f0833bb7ec5dc058549cff1
Implements: blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

methods in the implementation itself (like Neutron's CLI

backward-compatible with projects using ovsdbapp.

commit_message:
Make schema-agnostic db commands part of base API

The various OVSDB schemas and CLI utils all support the same
basic DB operations: get/set/add/clear/destroy/find/list. This
patch requires all backend implementations to support these ops
and will allow any schema implementations sharing a backend to
share those operations.

Since the implementations are already subclassing the
backend-agnostic API definitions and the backend db ops are
backend-specific and schema-agnostic partial implementations
themselves, the options for implementing this were mixins or
composition. This patch chooses mixins despite their
(usually deserved) bad repution. The Backend operations all
require access to the class they are mixed into (or would
be composed into). In the end, composition ended up being
more work for a less useful result.

An implementation would choose the Idl backend ops like:
from ovsdbapp.backend import ovs_idl

class MyOVSIdlImpl(ovs_idl.Backend, api.API):

If any implementation doesn't specify a backend (like Neutron's
CLI implementation), then it must define the Backend db_*
methods in the implementation itself (like Neutron's CLI
implementation already does). This means this change should be
backward-compatible with projects using ovsdbapp.

Change-Id: Iec53837de1205ab48b16ac7dc9b6eebdd8c4c400
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp refs/changes/52/469652/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl import commands cmd = commands.DbSetCommand(self.api, 'Interface', self.name, ('type', 'internal'))
deleted_lines: import collectionsimport six cmd = DbSetCommand(self.api, 'Interface', self.name, ('type', 'internal'))class DbCreateCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, **columns): super(DbCreateCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.columns = columns def run_idl(self, txn): row = txn.insert(self.api._tables[self.table]) for col, val in self.columns.items(): setattr(row, col, idlutils.db_replace_record(val)) # This is a temporary row to be used within the transaction self.result = row def post_commit(self, txn): # Replace the temporary row with the post-commit UUID to match vsctl self.result = txn.get_insert_uuid(self.result.uuid) class DbDestroyCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, record): super(DbDestroyCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.record = record def run_idl(self, txn): record = idlutils.row_by_record(self.api.idl, self.table, self.record) record.delete() class DbSetCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, record, *col_values): super(DbSetCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.record = record self.col_values = col_values def run_idl(self, txn): record = idlutils.row_by_record(self.api.idl, self.table, self.record) for col, val in self.col_values: # TODO(twilson) Ugh, the OVS library doesn't like OrderedDict # We're only using it to make a unit test work, so we should fix # this soon. if isinstance(val, collections.OrderedDict): val = dict(val) if isinstance(val, dict): # NOTE(twilson) OVS 2.6's Python IDL has mutate methods that # would make this cleaner, but it's too early to rely on them. existing = getattr(record, col, {}) existing.update(val) val = existing setattr(record, col, idlutils.db_replace_record(val)) class DbAddCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, record, column, *values): super(DbAddCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.record = record self.column = column self.values = values def run_idl(self, txn): record = idlutils.row_by_record(self.api.idl, self.table, self.record) for value in self.values: if isinstance(value, collections.Mapping): # We should be doing an add on a 'map' column. If the key is # already set, do nothing, otherwise set the key to the value # Since this operation depends on the previous value, verify() # must be called. field = getattr(record, self.column, {}) for k, v in six.iteritems(value): if k in field: continue field[k] = v else: # We should be appending to a 'set' column. try: record.addvalue(self.column, idlutils.db_replace_record(value)) continue except AttributeError: # OVS < 2.6 field = getattr(record, self.column, []) field.append(value) record.verify(self.column) setattr(record, self.column, idlutils.db_replace_record(field)) class DbClearCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, record, column): super(DbClearCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.record = record self.column = column def run_idl(self, txn): record = idlutils.row_by_record(self.api.idl, self.table, self.record) # Create an empty value of the column type value = type(getattr(record, self.column))() setattr(record, self.column, value) class DbGetCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, record, column): super(DbGetCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.record = record self.column = column def run_idl(self, txn): record = idlutils.row_by_record(self.api.idl, self.table, self.record) # TODO(twilson) This feels wrong, but ovs-vsctl returns single results # on set types without the list. The IDL is returning them as lists, # even if the set has the maximum number of items set to 1. Might be # able to inspect the Schema and just do this conversion for that case. result = idlutils.get_column_value(record, self.column) if isinstance(result, list) and len(result) == 1: self.result = result[0] else: self.result = result class DbListCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, records, columns, if_exists): super(DbListCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = table self.columns = columns self.if_exists = if_exists self.records = records def run_idl(self, txn): table_schema = self.api._tables[self.table] columns = self.columns or list(table_schema.columns.keys()) + ['_uuid'] if self.records: row_uuids = [] for record in self.records: try: row_uuids.append(idlutils.row_by_record( self.api.idl, self.table, record).uuid) except idlutils.RowNotFound: if self.if_exists: continue # NOTE(kevinbenton): this is converted to a RuntimeError # for compat with the vsctl version. It might make more # sense to change this to a RowNotFoundError in the future. raise RuntimeError( "Row doesn't exist in the DB. Request info: " "Table=%(table)s. Columns=%(columns)s. " "Records=%(records)s." % { "table": self.table, "columns": self.columns, "records": self.records}) else: row_uuids = table_schema.rows.keys() self.result = [ { c: idlutils.get_column_value(table_schema.rows[uuid], c) for c in columns } for uuid in row_uuids ] class DbFindCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, table, *conditions, **kwargs): super(DbFindCommand, self).__init__(api) self.table = self.api._tables[table] self.conditions = conditions self.columns = (kwargs.get('columns') or list(self.table.columns.keys()) + ['_uuid']) def run_idl(self, txn): self.result = [ { c: idlutils.get_column_value(r, c) for c in self.columns } for r in self.table.rows.values() if idlutils.row_match(r, self.conditions) ]

commit_message:
Better handle key=value pair not being key=value

Previously, --block-device and --ephemeral would error out with an
insctrutable (to the user) error message if one of the key=value pair
it expects wasn't actually key=value, for instance:

nova --block-device 995abd81-2626-413c-9af6-51f105fab214,tag=foo \
     --image CirrOS --flavor custom my_instance

ValueError: dictionary update sequence element #0 has length 1; 2 is
required

This patch makes the error message clearer.

Change-Id: I2dd5dd805df2b0382b015dc625205119d7d0b03b
